definition: Self-evident or unquestionable.
Something or someone puzzling, mysterious or inexplicable.

The branch of philosophy dealing with the study of knowledge; theory of knowledge, asking such questions as "What is knowledge?", "How is knowledge acquired?", "What do people know?", "How do we know what we know?".
System of doctrines concerning final matters, such as death.
Without preparation or advanced thought; offhand.
Of the same kind; alike, similar.
Peculiar to a specific individual; eccentric.
Beyond expression in words; unspeakable.
Of or pertaining to metaphysics.
To ban a person from a city for five or ten years through the procedure of ostracism.
A pattern, a way of doing something, especially a pattern of thought, a system of beliefs, a conceptual framework.
Having self-contradictory properties.
Done only to fulfil a duty, or in a careless or indifferent manner; performed mechanically and as a thing of rote.
Of acute discernment; having keen insight; mentally perceptive.
One who has mastered, notably speaks, several languages.
Versed in, or speaking, many languages.
Possessing or acting with the desire to do noble and romantic deeds, without thought of realism and practicality; exceedingly idealistic.
Shiny and colourful, and thus pleasing to the eye.
Keeping one's thoughts and opinions to oneself; reserved or restrained.
Being everywhere at once: omnipresent.
Causing vexation or annoyance; teasing; troublesome.
Difficult to comprehend or understand.
Harsh and sharp, or bitter and not pleasant to the taste; acrid, pungent.
Erroneous in date; containing an anachronism; in a wrong time; not applicable to or not appropriate for the time.
A proposition that is the diametric opposite of some other proposition.
Of good omen; indicating future success.
A mix of discordant sounds; dissonance.
Impulsive and unpredictable; determined by chance, impulse, or whim
A roundabout or indirect way of speaking; the use of more words than necessary to express an idea.
Reasonable and convincing; based on evidence.
Having elements of a feast or of entertainment, especially when it comes to eating and drinking, with accompanying festivity
Excessively ready to believe things; gullible.
A period or condition when food is rare and hence expensive; famine.
A treatise on teaching or education.
Instructive or intended to teach or demonstrate, especially with regard to morality.
To throw into a state of confusion; to befuddle or perplex.
Inequality in marriage; marriage with an inferior.
To match unequally; to degrade or dishonor.
Enthusiastic; high-spirited.
Someone who selects according to the eclectic method.
Selecting a mixture of what appears to be best of various doctrines, methods or styles.
(of a liquid) Giving off bubbles; fizzy.

To use words of equivocal or doubtful signification; to express one's opinions in terms which admit of different senses, with intent to deceive; to use ambiguous expressions with a view to mislead; as, to equivocate is the work of duplicity.
The use of a word or phrase to replace another with one that is considered less offensive, blunt or vulgar than the word or phrase which it replaces.
That evokes (brings to mind) a memory, mood, feeling or image; redolent or reminiscent
Fast, prompt, speedy.
Stealthy.
(of a person) Describing one who enjoys being in crowds and socializing.
Very unlucky; ill-fated.
An impassioned, disputatious public speech.
To give a forceful and lengthy lecture or criticism to someone.
Excessive pride, presumption or arrogance (originally toward the gods).
Beyond expression in words; unspeakable.
Impossible to prevent or stop; inevitable.
One who or that which is inscrutable; a person, etc. that cannot be comprehended.
Difficult or impossible to comprehend, fathom or interpret.
Lacking enthusiasm, energy, or strength; drooping or flagging from weakness, fatigue, or lack of energy
A feeling of general bodily discomfort, fatigue or unpleasantness, often at the onset of illness.
Characterized by very precise, conscientious attention to details.
Emerging; just coming into existence.
Sinful, villainous, criminal, or wicked, especially when noteworthy or notorious for such characteristics.
To make dark; overshadow
Obfuscated; darkened; obscured.
Obedient; compliant with someone else's orders or wishes.
Of ostentation.
Capable of being touched, felt or handled; touchable, tangible.
A person of preeminent qualities, who acts as a pattern or model for others.
To compare; to parallel; to put in rivalry or emulation with.
Like a pedant, overly concerned with formal rules and trivial points of learning.
Causing much harm in a subtle way.
A feeling of enmity; ill-feeling, animosity; a transient feeling of wounded pride.
To wound the pride of; to excite to anger.
To calm; to bring peace to; to influence someone who was furious to the point that they become content or at least no longer irate.
Dangerously insecure or unstable; perilous.
The particular character or essence of someone or something; individuality.
Naturally aggressive or hostile; combative; belligerent; bellicose.
A swampy, soggy area of ground.
To embroil (a person, etc.) in complexity or difficulty.
Often complaining; suggesting a complaint in expression; fretful, whining.
To summarize or repeat in concise form.
A person who is recalcitrant.
Marked by a stubborn unwillingness to obey authority.
To reject the truth or validity of; to deny.
An outwardly projecting part of a fortification, trench system, or line of defense.
Worthy of note; pertinent or relevant.
Scornfully mocking or cynical.
A combination of events which have come together by chance to make a surprisingly good or wonderful outcome.
Something inducing sleep, especially a drug.
(pharmaceutical effect) Tending to induce sleep.
One who has a strong build.
Firmly or solidly built.
Stealthy, furtive, well hidden, covert (especially movements).
Silent; temperamentally untalkative; disinclined to speak.
A fearful state; a state of concern or hesitation.
(of a liquid or substance) Oily or greasy.
Abounding in words, containing more words than necessary; long-winded.
Of or relating to the viscera—internal organs of the body.
Given to whimsy.
Full of longing or yearning.
The act of wandering; deviation from truth, moral rectitude; abnormal; divergence from the straight, correct, proper, normal, or from the natural state.
An absolving of sins from ecclesiastical penalties by an authority.
The process of amalgamating; a mixture, merger or consolidation.
A deviation from a rule or from what is regarded as normal; an outlier.
A feeling of dislike (normally towards someone, less often towards something); repugnance or distaste.
Understood by only a few.
The vanguard of an army or other force.
Innovative, pioneering, especially when extremely or obviously so.
Common in a boring way, to the point of being predictable; containing nothing new or fresh.
A great and mighty beast God shows Job in Job 40:15–24.
Warlike in nature; aggressive; hostile.
(of a person, their language or writing) showy in speech and given to using flowery or elaborate terms; grandiloquent; pompous
To surrender; to end all resistance, to give up; to go along with or comply.
Deception by use of trickery, quibbling, or subterfuge.
Of or pertaining to a serf, peasant, or rustic.
Carefully aware of all circumstances; considerate of all that is pertinent.
A colloquial word or phrase, colloquialism
Denoting a manner of speaking or writing that is characteristic of familiar conversation, of common parlance; informal.
Harmful often in a subtle or unexpected way.
To criticise so as to besmirch; traduce, disparage or defame.
An abusive, bitter, attack or criticism: denunciation.
A separation or division into two; a distinction that results in such a division.
(chiefly in the plural) Any of a group of unequal or dissimilar things.
Composed of inherently different or distinct elements; incongruous.
A harsh, discordant combination of sounds.
Something which lasts for a short period of time.
Lasting for a short period of time.
The appearance of Jesus Christ to the Magi on the twelfth day after Christmas.
An illuminating realization or discovery, often resulting in a personal feeling of elation, awe, or wonder.
The embodiment or encapsulation of a class of items.
Pertaining to the hypothetical upper, purer air, or to the higher regions beyond the earth or beyond the atmosphere; celestial; otherworldly.
To make worse (a problem, bad situation, negative feeling, etc.); aggravate; exasperate.
To relieve (someone or something) of a load; to unburden (a load).
Freed from an obligation; freed from accusation or blame; acquitted, exonerated.
To praise; to make high.
Treating serious issues with (often deliberately) inappropriate humour; flippant.
Excessively particular, demanding, or fussy about details, especially about tidiness and cleanliness.
To confuse; to fluster; to flabbergast.
To make glib.
Having a ready flow of words but lacking thought or understanding; superficial; shallow.
Domination, influence, or authority over another, especially by one political group over a society or by one nation over others.
Someone who believes contrary to the fundamental tenets of a religion they claim to belong to.
Heretical; of or pertaining to heresy or heretics.
Unaffected or unable to be affected by something.
Making arbitrary decisions, especially in an impulsive and forceful manner.
Not similar or congruent; not matching or fitting in.
A derogatory hint or reference to a person or thing. An implication, intimation or insinuation.
To interpret (something libellous or slanderous) in terms of what was implied.
Producing harm in a stealthy, often gradual, manner.
A person who is insolent.
Insulting in manner or words.
To place side by side, especially for contrast or comparison.
To lose strength and become weak; to be in a state of weakness or sickness.
Gloomy, mournful or dismal, especially to an exaggerated degree.
To feign illness, injury, or incapacitation in order to avoid work, obligation, or perilous risk.
The Magdalene; Mary Magdalene.
Affectionate or sentimental in an effusive, tearful, or foolish manner, especially because of drunkenness.
Black bile, formerly thought to be one of the four "cardinal humours" of animal bodies.
Affected with great sadness or depression.
To ease a burden, particularly worry; make less painful; to comfort.
A short-sighted individual.
Near-sighted; unable to see distant objects unaided
In the form of a cloud or haze; hazy.
A beginner; a person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief.
A longing for home or familiar surroundings; homesickness.
Of or pertaining to an omen or to omens; being or exhibiting an omen; significant.
Of or relating to a palace.
A remedy believed to cure all disease and prolong life that was originally sought by alchemists; a cure-all.
A person who is rejected from society or home; an outcast.
To act as a patron of; to defend, protect, or support.
Like a pedant, overly concerned with formal rules and trivial points of learning.
Taste, liking, or inclination (for).
Of, pertaining to, or representing perfidy; disloyal to what should command one's fidelity or allegiance.
Childishly irritable
Seemingly or apparently valid, likely, or acceptable; conceivably true or likely
Characterized by exceptionally early development or maturity.
Condition of favoring or liking; tendency towards; proclivity; predisposition.
A predisposition or natural inclination, propensity, or a predilection; especially, a strong disposition or bent.
The deep; the sea; the ocean.
To cause to sink deeply; to cause to dive or penetrate far down.
Descending far below the surface; opening or reaching to great depth; deep.
Fertile; producing offspring or fruit in abundance — applied to plants producing fruit, animals producing young, etc.

Sagacious in adapting means to ends; circumspect in action, or in determining any line of conduct; careful, discreet, sensible; — opposed to rash; directed by prudence or wise forethought; evincing prudence
One who fights with his fists; especially a professional prize fighter; a boxer.
The deepest malignity or spite; deep-seated enmity or malice; inveterate hatred.
The art of using language, especially public speaking, as a means to persuade.
Part of or similar to rhetoric, the use of language as a means to persuade.
False, not authentic, not genuine.
To sublimate.
One who uses obsequious compliments to gain self-serving favor or advantage from another; a servile flatterer.
To inform against; hence, to calumniate.
Thin in substance or consistency.
A feeling of anger or annoyance caused by something offensive.
To displease or cause offense.
(of a person) The quality of speaking or stating the truth; truthfulness.
To say defamatory things about someone or something; to speak ill of.
Of or pertaining to vitriol; derived from or resembling vitriol.
Making or characterized by a noisy outcry; clamorous.
A xenophobe.
Exhibiting or characterised by xenophobia, a fear or hatred of strangers or foreigners
Something characteristic of a zealot; excessive zeal; fanaticism.
